= null =

== Syntax ==
Constant: '''null'''

== Description ==
The '''null''' keyword represents a null pointer value in DIL. It is used to indicate that a pointer variable does not point to any valid object or unit. This is particularly useful when working with unitptr, extraptr, cmdptr, and other pointer types.

The '''null''' value is equivalent to a nullptr in C/C++ and can be used in comparisons to check if a pointer is valid or to explicitly set a pointer to no value.

== Usage Notes ==
* '''null''' can be used with any pointer type (unitptr, extraptr, cmdptr, etc.)
* Many functions return '''null''' to indicate failure or that no object was found
* '''null''' is commonly used as a parameter in functions like '''act()''' where a medium argument is optional
* When comparing pointers, use `== null` or `!= null` to check for null values

== Examples ==
=== Basic Usage ===
 dilbegin check_pointer();
 var
    my_unit : unitptr;
 
 code
 {
    my_unit := findunit(self, "sword", FIND_UNIT_INVEN, null);
    if (my_unit == null)
       act("You don't have a sword.", A_ALWAYS, self, null, null, TO_CHAR);
    else
       act("You found your sword!", A_ALWAYS, self, null, null, TO_CHAR);
 } dilend

=== Function Parameters ===
 dilbegin use_null_in_act();
 var
    target : unitptr;
 
 code
 {
    // Using null as the medium parameter in act()
    act("You look around.", A_SOMEONE, self, null, null, TO_CHAR);
    
    target := findunit(self, "guard", FIND_UNIT_SURRO, null);
    if (target != null)
       act("You see $1n here.", A_SOMEONE, self, target, null, TO_CHAR);
 } dilend

=== Setting Pointers to Null ===
 dilbegin reset_pointers();
 var
    saved_unit : unitptr;
 
 code
 {
    saved_unit := self;  // Save current unit
    // ... do some work ...
    saved_unit := null;  // Reset to null when done
 } dilend

== Error Handling ==
When working with functions that return pointers, always check for '''null''' before using the returned value to avoid runtime errors:

 if (returned_pointer != null)
 {
    // Safe to use the pointer
 }
 else
 {
    // Handle the null case
 }
